statement.tex: %text Two pipes, when used together can fill a tank in $12$ minutes. Individually however, one pipe takes $7$ minutes longer than the other pipe to fill the same tank. How long do each of the pipes take to fill the tank on their own? %

\\ %text If the volume of the tank is V, and the time it takes for the slower pipe to fill the tank on its own is ${\bf t}$, what are the rates $R_1$ and $R_2$ at which each of the pipes fill the tank? %
\\ %text If $R_1$ and $R_2$ are the individual rates for each of the pipes, what is the effective rate $R_{eff}$ when both pipes are filling the tank together? %
\\ %text $R_1=\dfrac{V}{t}$,$R_2=\dfrac{V}{t+7}$ and $R_{eff}=R_1+R_2$. If $R_{eff}=\dfrac{V}{12}$, what is ${\bf t}$, the time it took for the slower pipe to fill the tank? %

reason.tex: %text For any number of pipes filling the tank simultaneously, the effective rate is the sum of all the individual rates. $R_{eff}=\sum_{i=1}^n R_i$ %

\begin{align} &R_{eff}=R_1+R_2 \\ \implies &\dfrac{V}{12}=\dfrac{V}{t}+\dfrac{V}{t+7} \\ \implies &t^2+7t=12(2t+7) \\ \implies &t^2-17t-84=0 \\ \implies &t^2-21t+4t-84=0 \\ \implies &t(t-21)+4(t-21)=0 \\ \implies &t=21, -4 \end{align} \\ %text Rejecting the negative values for time, we get $t=21$. %
